ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Given the problems of bias and identifiability, course evaluations seem deeply problematic.
An excellent opportunity to read, discuss and reflect on some important foundational texts in sociology. Yes, I would recommend this course for reasons outlined in question 1.

The course offers an overview of the canon of sociological theory through in-class discussions of the assigned readings, which range from Marx, Hegel and Smith to Bourdieu and Foucault.Yes, this course provided a great survey of the literature in sociology.
Absolutely yes. You have a great opportunity to think about what the role of sociological theory in your own study.
It's a thought-provoking, rich course that scratches the surface of sociological theory. I would definitely recommend it--discussions were fun and readings were great.
I would recommend Sociology 542 to other students without reservation.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: Given the problems of bias and identifiability, course evaluations seem deeply problematic.
This course gave me a great foundation in sociological theory and a familiarity with some of the great texts in sociology, including Durkheim, Hegel, Marx, and Weber.

The focus on formative works in the field was invaluable. In fact, I wish there were more courses like this, where a number of classic works are explored in depth. This sort of training seems critical for our future ability to teach a variety of sociology courses.
